Jim,

While I am reading kantei #2 and becoming familiar
with the groups people are talking about, you didn't
give me a chance to ask a question back on #1.  Is it
possible to get picture of the tekkotsu from kanayama
for comparison?  I am visual, there is a dirty joke in
there, and that would really help sink it into the
brain.

Very interesting all of this.  I have lots of books I
just purchased and several months of reading.  Just
have to finish the sword section of the boston museum
and I'm into 4 or 5 tsuba books.  Hopefully, I can
start to get a handle on some of this.  So I wouldn't
even begin to give an answer.  

Thanks again.
Ken

--- Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wrote:

> The scan of the front of the guard does not do it
> justice, but is sufficient to see what's there.  The
> photos of the mimi give some sense of the tekkotsu
> that place the guard in the Owari region.  Given the
> shape of the rim and the design, the two most likely
> choices are Kanayama and Owari sukashi.  I think
> either answer is acceptable given that you are
> working from pictures.
> 
> The thickness and somewhat squared rim lean toward
> Kanayama, but can also be seen in Owari work.  The
> guard is on the thick end of the spectrum for either
> type.  The diameter is possible for either group,
> although on the large side for Kanayama.  The style
> of the tekkotsu is the most important point. 
> Kanayama tekkotsu tend to form pronounced, sometimes
> rough bumps.  Owari tekkotsu are low, smooth and
> emerge from the plate with more subtlety, forming
> "bean" shaped and "rope" forms.  This guard shows
> both of these latter types.  Also, Kanayama guards
> will often show some tekkotsu on the face, but Owari
> guards do not.
> 
> Wild goose designs are common in Owari work.  It's
> not impossible to imagine a design like this in a
> Kanayama guard, but it is more naturalistic,
> complicated and even a little delicate for that
> group.  The majority of the evidence points toward
> Owari sukashi.
> 
> The guard is in very good condition, so it may look
> younger than it is.  The quality of the iron and the
> tekkotsu are unlikely to date to the early Edo
> period, and are consistent with pieces from mid to
> late Muromachi.  The birds at the top and bottom of
> the sukashi design seem too free spirited to be from
> that time, though and seem more like Momoyama. 
> Given that design is easier to manipulate than iron,
> I lean toward late Muromachi, but Momoyama is
> possible.
> 
> The guard has a kanteisho to Owari from the NBTHK. 
> No date given.
> 
> Yagyu is in the correct region, but the texture of
> the metal will be cloudy/sandy and will tend to show
> many linear laminations in the rim.  It is also not
> a Yagyu design.
> 
> I included this tsuba in the Akasaka display at
> Tampa to show the likely Owari origins of the
> Akasaka group.  While some Ko-Akasaka guards will
> show tekkotsu, they are not of this type and the
> color and texture of the iron is different.  The rim
> would show a more rounded shape in Akasaka.  The
> cutting of the sukashi would have sharper edges. 
> The design does have a bit of Akasaka feeling, but
> there would probably be more asymmetry and
> abstraction in an Akasaka piece.
> 
> That's all I can think of at the moment.  Any other
> observations or questions?
> 
> Jim
> 
> 
> 
>   OK, here is a guard for kantei:
> 
>  
>
http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/2964?c
> 
>   77.0 mm H x 74.8 mm W, 7.2 mm thick at the mimi
> and 7.1 mm thick at the seppa dai.
> 
> 
>   As far as I know it has not been published, but it
> has been exhibited at a couple of study meetings. 
> So, if you've already seen it and remember the
> attribution, please don't post the answer to the
> list.  It is mumei and there are two almost equally
> reasonable attributions, but I think that there is
> more evidence for one than the other.
> 
>   Respond with your bid on or off list as you
> prefer.
> 
>   Jim
>
